review_title: A lot to learn, lots of opportunities
pros:
Accenture is a company that is not going anywhere. If you are good at your job, it's stable and reliable employment. Many people are very loyal to Accenture and have worked there for decades. This sends a message that Accenture treats employees well.

Working with some incredibly smart and talented people. Most people are approachable no matter what their title, and will make time to talk or offer feedback/suggestions. 

Tons of resources to learn and help - research, templates. guides, etc.

I didn't have to 'prove myself' when I started. The people I worked with assumed that I was competent and skilled in my area, and listened to me immediately.

Diversity efforts are real, not just talk.
cons:
Accenture can be overwhelming at first due to the sheer size of the company and the fast pace. There isn't much time to onboard or train before starting to dig into the work.

Health insurance costs are a little high.

It's easy to get lost in the shuffle or stuck in a role. Moving to a new role within the company is more difficult than the company would have you believe.

job_title: Quality Monitoring Feedback Associate in Dublin, Dublin
pros:
I've heard many bad things about Accenture. I can say at least in my case and the current project that I work in that the experience has been great so far.
-Salary isn't the best when starting but it's okay as long as you're working from home. Compensates by not having to spend money on transportation and other things. 
-Management so far has been amazing.
-I've never been told No to my requests, not that I have asked much but I'm also hardworking so can't complain, when they'll say no I'll start working less. Just to compensate :).
-Plenty of promotion opportunities, usually fair from my experience. If you work well, not much and bad, but well and you're active to make yourself known a promotion is pretty much possible.
-Private health insurance included.
cons:
-The roster, I can't stand it. It's unpredictable in different situations. Make the roster 6/3 or 4/2 for God's sake if you need coverage 7 days a week and that way it will be quite fair for everyone.
-20 days of paid leave. Unfair, should be at least 24/25. 
-A few more little perks would be more than welcome.

review_title: No overtime pay. Limited self development program. Limited employee benefit
pros: Good brand. Got into this company will increase your CV value. Company is already mature, have a structured career hierarchy. The promotion mechanism is quite clear.
cons: Been (almost) always worked overtime in my first project, where worked more than 12 hours a day, yet got no cent at all. Comparing with Accenture in other country, there was no benefit such as sign-on bonus, vendor bonus, or project bonus. The health benefit also has very limited coverage. Most of the time I always spend my own money for health service. The self-development does not exist. What management care is to work as what client demand, although employee does not have technical expertise (since there is no adequate training program).

review_title: Good choice for a career start but take everything with a pinch of salt
pros:
- Colleagues are great, very helpful for beginners. 
- Some projects are very interesting so you learn a lot of things (e.g., redesign a process from the bottom up). 
- You get perks that you might not receive in non-corporate environments in Greece (i.e., private health insurance).
cons:
- People are scarce which means you have a heavy workload and you might move around projects to fill the gaps
- Pay is average and you can barely afford to live on your own
- Overtime is generally ignored, you spend like an hour during the onboarding where they go back and forth about the various types of overtime and how to report it and in the end you get nothing unless you end work at 11pm every day. 
- Especially if you return from abroad, they might try to lure you by promising early promotions, pay increases etc. Just ignore you've ever heard that stuff

job_title: Senior Strategy Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: You get used to the long hours and unreasonable asks, and for better or for worse, this can help you find out where your boundaries are. When you leave, you'll be in high demand because of name recognition, and you can find a place that values you as much as you really should be.
cons: Staffing model forces you to fend for yourself way too often and fake network with too many people who just want to use you as a foot soldier. I was one of the poor souls put on an extremely micromanaged, emotionally stressful call center project as soon as I started, and it made me realize that I did not want to work for a company that would treat their employees like this just to keep a big contract. There's a lot of red tape if you want to publish any thought leadership that is remotely going to possibly upset any client. It's hierarchical because it's consulting. I expected this but it was still bad enough for me to leave before making consultant.

pros: 1 - Good work life balance. 2 - Opportunities to upskill. 3 - Variety of domain/technologies to work on. 4 - Competitive Salary. 5 - Free Transport and good security for Female employees.

pros: Nice place to work. Nice Team for working in projects
cons: they don't pay the same of the market for the same position

pros:
The pay is good. They determine it based on where you live. 
People here are very smart from a variety of backgrounds.
They have an employee resource group for everyone. It helps you feel included and validated. If one doesnt exist you can create it.
There is some travel. It can be good or bad.
cons:
Supposedly I have a people lead. Supposedly we should be talking to them several times a year. I have to actively hound my people lead for a meeting even then he reschedules like 4 times before we meet.
I have no idea how promotions work. Supposedly if I do next career level work and prove it I can get promoted. But honestly its very subjective.
It can be taxing mentally when you work on a role then have to scramble to find a new role asap when you roll off. If you have any unstaffed time they monitor that and Ive heard of people getting let go for too much unstaffed time.
Training is a mess. You can only have 40 hours of training a year. 
For internal training I did the first time manager training and no where in my internal career page is there a place for me to enter that I took this training to let people know I can do managerial work.
They have a lot of roles for salesforce, workday, tableu and other niche applications. Yet I cannot find training for any of them.
Requesting training is convoluted.

review_title: Management Consulting - A Quagmire of Sorts
pros:
- Well remunerated - Accenture really seeks to be a benchmark in compensating well across all roles 
- International Colleagues - Accenture provides the opportunity to meet talented individuals from so many different countries 
- Broad Exposure - you will do so many different things at Accenture, your knowledge and skillset will only grow 
- Fast Pace - genuinely, you learn to deliver at pace you never knew
cons:
- Established networks that are not welcoming to new starters 
- Intensive non-stop admin within HR 
- Repetitive requests - the same requests from so many different stakeholders/market units in different formats, you spend your day answering emails all asking for the same info in different formats 
- Bottom 10% - every year people need to end up in the bottom is this really necessary!!!
- Lack of execution from HR - a HR Team more dedicated to politics than delivery, execution & delivery...

review_title: Uma ótima empresa para começar carreira e ascender, mas alguns pontos
job_title: Analista Engenheiro de Dados Sênior in Fortaleza, Ceará
pros: - Companhia humanizada, que cuida dos seus colaboradores e possui diversas ações que trabalham em diferentes frentes sociais, culturais e educacionais; - Colabora para certificações (principalmente em computação em nuvem), fornecendo voucher 100% para obtenção de certificações. - Possui uma grande quantidade de consultores altamente especializados, com certeza você irá aprender muito com eles. - Projetos grandes e para clientes grandes. Irá agregar muito no seu currículo. - A companhia possui um clima agradável, flexível e organizado. - Home-office. - Plano de carreira muito bem definido.
cons: - Progressão salarial é muito demorada. Você só consegue aumento salarial se subir de cargo, isso acaba contribuindo para maior demora, mesmo tendo uma boa performance, podendo levar de 1,6 a 2 anos para ter algum aumento salarial, mesmo tendo bom desempenho e avaliação do cliente + lideranças Accenture. - Salários abaixo da média de mercado. A companhia tenta lhe comprar com um bom ambiente e benefícios. Dependendo dos seus objetivos, isso somado a lenta progressão podem ser um incomodo (foi meu caso). - VR podia ser melhor. A Accenture usa BEN e, pelo menos em Fortaleza, ele não pega em todos os lugares, além disso o aplicativo é ruim pois ele informa que estabelecimento X passa o cartão e chega lá não passa (gera até um constrangimento). - Até o nível de cargo Sênior, você terá maior contato apenas com cliente e pessoas da Accenture que trabalham no mesmo time que você. A impressão é que você é mais do cliente do que da Accenture. Para alguns pode ser algo incômodo. - Somando com o ponto acima, dependendo do cliente, você pode enfrentar pessoas tóxicas / cultura tóxica do cliente. Isso pode gerar um estresse, mas a Accenture costuma prestar bastante suporte para esses casos. - Além disso, a Accenture não possui muitos produtos próprios, então a sua atuação provavelmente será dentro de consultoria atuando em projetos específicos para clientes em específico.

pros: Accenture has a wide range of technology stacks that you can work with. Can do almost anything in tech. Lots of social events, good facilities in office. Free lunches.
cons: The opportunities are wide, however finding projects can also be difficult, need to do lots of networking and upskilling initially (typical at consulting firms). Good for overall development though. Salary is below market average but also typical for consulting firms. They do provides lots of benefits though, depending on your project, they can fly you out interstate. Large company means lots of opportunities but also can feel invisible compared to smaller companies.

review_title: Big Clients, Impactful Work ... but requires Drive and Determination
pros: Accenture is a good place for any technologist to develop a broad spectrum of skills, which serves as a stable foundation for one's future. The client challenges are real, complex, and it requires the individual to develop a flexible mind to see problems from multiple dimensions, and identify opportunities to chart a way forward. This skill, developed continuously over time, will serve one well in the more advanced stages of their career. At the same time, there is a tremendous range of support and resources that are provided for the individual to make use of; the only challenge will be on the time that is available to make the full use of these - but for one who is determined, this will undoubtedly accelerate the pace of their advancement both technically and professionally.
cons: Like most companies that cross the 10,000 employee mark, it becomes harder to ensure consistency. With a workforce of over 700K, and the UK workforce surpassing 10,000, one's career experience might vary depending on the project, peers, and reporting structure. Most of the negative reviews centre around a person's dissatisfaction with the promotion process, and the work involved to ensure the strongest possibility of getting promoted; this ranges from project feedback, representation in the appraisal process, and visibility. Balancing this many factors is a formidable challenge. Changes in a large organisation culture, or operating model take time - even if the benefits of change have been apparent for a while, convincing a sufficiently large critical mass of the leadership team is going to require one of two things: the decision is comes from a much higher authority, or the problem grows to an extent where its at the magnitude of a crisis, and cannot be ignored any longer. For the individual, it might be too costly (in terms of the personal impact) to wait for such transformation to eventually happen.

pros: - Pay is good - Accenture is involved in just about every professional services offering out there - Exposure at a young age to a plethora of different offerings/roles is great - Exposure to senior level management on ACN and client-side is great (depending on the role) - Flexibility of work: mostly remote still, but can attend the office whenever for networking purposes, etc. - Impressive workforce: the people at Accenture are impressive and motivated
cons: - Lack of transparency/communication on performance - Difficulty transitioning across firm to areas of interest, despite breadth of offerings/opportunities - No people managers: the managers/MDs you work for are not judged based on their development of you; hard to find people who look out for you/people who stay at the firm long enough to stay connected to. Because of this, it’s easy to get pigeon-holed into an area that you’re not really passionate about because you just want to stick with the few people you’re close to in your network. - Sometimes feels like your hard work goes unappreciated (dependent on manager, but this happened often) - Often expected to work over a 40 hour week to meet crazy tight deadlines (When you’re more experienced) - Can be tough as an new analyst or consultant to get your first role at that level as the expectations are high and they’ll typically prefer a more seasoned analyst/consultant to fill the position

pros: The learning scope of good. Latest and cutting edge technologies are implemented in Accenture. Facilities and benefits are ok. Good consideration to female employees for promotion, hiring, benefits, etc. is given in Accenture.
cons:
When I joined Accenture as a fresher it was really excited until 3-4 years. But after post COVID lockdown, the work culture has suddenly deteriorated in Accenture. The new managers that have been hired are really pathetic.
Previously the management used to take care of employees and their concerns. Now if you raise one concern, the managers in India would threaten you, for example, saying that, "you should feel lucky that atleast you have a job" or "your job is in my hands".
Working for at least 11-12 hrs have become a norm in Accenture and if you complain, the words of managers will take you into depression.
Even the new joiners are not treated well, and expectation is to start working effectively even without proper KTs.
Project Managers lack Empathy and their way of talking is degrading day by day.
